vi  EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
The primary goal of the World Bank Institute (WBI) is to provide knowledge services to build institutional capacity in client countries. In FY03, WBI launched a new approach to providing services that are country-focused, multi-year programs linked to Bank country assistance strategies and the client's own poverty reduction goals. WBI in coordination with Regional Vice Presidencies identified a group of 30 countries in which to concentrate this new approach initially, starting in FY04.
In support of the country-focused approach, WBI's Evaluation Group (IEG) concurrently initiated a series of evaluations to establish country-specific results to serve as baselines in the priority countries. This report focuses on WBI activities implemented in Kenya in FY02 and FY03.
The evaluation addresses the following three main questions.
· What is the relevance of WBI learning activities to Kenya and Kenyan participants?
· What are the effectiveness and impact of WBI learning activities?
· Do WBI activities have a sustained presence and comparative advantage in Kenya?
The sections below provide a summary of the methodology, main findings, and key recommendations.
METHODOLOGY
The evaluation is based on multiple sources of data, including participant questionnaires, participant focus group discussions, interviews with Bank staff working on Kenya, and a review of the 1998 Kenya CAS and WBI FY02-04 CRS data. A Kenya- based consulting firm collected the participant data in early 2004 from a 20 percent random sample of Kenyan participants. The participant response rate was 92 percent.
MAINFINDINGS
The Client Recording System data is missing contact information on a substantial proportion, 35 percent, of Kenyan participants, thereby excluding the possibility for follow-up for further learning activities or for evaluation.
FY02 and FY03 WBI activities tended to be of short to medium duration and involved small numbers of participants from Kenya: about a quarter of the learning activities lasted for three or fewer days and 39 percent lasted for three and a half to five days. More than 70 percent involved only one to five participants from Kenya.
vii  A large majority, sixty nine percent of Kenyan participants' perceived the activity they attended to be highly relevant to Kenya's specific needs, but only 44 percent considered the activity to be highly relevant to their work.
The alignment of WBI's FY02 and FY03 activities to the 1998 CAS recommendations was 56 percent, indicating that a substantial proportion of WBI programs delivered were unrelated to the country strategy articulated in the CAS. It should be noted, however, that the Bank program changed substantially between 1998 and 2002, due to the changes in political circumstances, and therefore the activities may have been more aligned with the Bank's approach. The WBI-CAS alignment index should improve with the implementation of WBI's country-focused approach and the development of the new 2004 CAS.
Participants' ratings reveal that WBI activities were moderately effective, but their impact was less significant. Only 45 to 27 percent of the participants reported high use, and 11 to 24 percent made little to no use, of knowledge and skills in specific domains relevant to their work. Seventeen to 24 percent of the participants made little use of knowledge and skills they gained for work practices, country development, and influencing legislation, suggesting that the activity they attended did not lend itself to use for direct institutional/country development purposes.
The development of action plans during activity implementation and participants' perceived activity relevance to Kenya's needs and to their own work were significant predictors of activity effectiveness. Effectiveness in turn was significantly related to the participants' use of the knowledge and skills they gained in the learning activity. However, only 45 percent of the activities appear to have included the development of action plans as a pedagogical strategy for achieving outcomes.
Activity relevance to work, its effectiveness for addressing organizational needs, and the participants' use of knowledge and skills for influencing legislation were on the lower end of participant ratings, suggesting that the activities did not adequately target the institutional dimensions of capacity building.
WBI's comparative advantage in Kenya is clear; fewer than 25 percent of the participants were aware of similar activities being offered by other organizations. On average, participants rated WBI activities to be more useful than those of other organizations.
Despite this advantage, WBI activities did not have a sustained presence in Kenya. On the positive side, 68 percent of the participants reported receiving contact information for fellow participants. On the negative side, nearly 53 percent of the participants reported that there was no follow-up contact by WBI.
Participant and Bank staff feedback suggests that lack of follow-up and non-strategic targeting of Kenyan audiences was a significant barrier to institutionalizing capacity building and realizing impact.
viii  RECOMMENDATIONS
WBI's demand-driven, country-focused direction in support of CAS should improve the overall relevance of WBI activities FY04 and beyond. Nonetheless, key activity design, implementation, and targeting will need attention, if sustained institutional impact is the goal of WBI presence in Kenya. Some recommendations follow.
· Design activities that include follow-up and on-going contact with participants. Activities of this nature will require a careful targeting of participants, with help from the Kenya country team, for institutional impact.
· Include action plans as part of activity implementation to help participants apply what they learn to their jobs.
· Improve CRS participant information. Demand for activities with more WBI follow-up and on-going contact should create an incentive for WBI task managers to gather and report accurate participant contact information.
ix  x  1. INTRODUCTION
1.1 The primary goal of the World Bank Institute (WBI) is to provide knowledge services to build institutional capacity in client countries. In FY03, the Institute initiated a new approach to providing services that are country-focused, multi-year programs linked to the Bank's country assistance strategies and the client's own poverty reduction goals.1
1.2 To launch this customized approach, WBI in coordination with Regional Vice Presidencies identified a group of 30 countries in which to concentrate its country- focused capacity enhancement approach initially, starting in FY04.
1.3 As part of its evaluation mandate, the Institute Evaluation Group (IEG) initiated a series of evaluations to establish country-specific results to serve as baselines going forward in the priority countries. In FY03, these countries were Brazil, Egypt, Russia, Sri Lanka, and Thailand, and in FY04, the evaluations were extended to include Burkina Faso, Guatemala, Indonesia, Kenya, Nigeria, Tajikistan, and Yemen (see Table 1). This report takes as its focus the effectiveness and impact of WBI activities implemented in Kenya in FY02 and FY03.

2  2. EVALUATION METHODOLOGY
2.1 The evaluation addresses the following three main questions.
· What is the relevance of WBI learning activities to Kenya and Kenyan participants?
· What are the effectiveness and impact of WBI learning activities?
· Do WBI activities have a sustained presence and comparative advantage in Kenya?
2.2 We used a combination of quantitative and qualitative data collection methods and sources of information to answer these questions, including: (a) a quantitative survey of a sample of Kenyan participants; (b) qualitative interviews with members of the Bank's Kenya country team; (c) a focus group of participants of select WBI activities; and (d) a review of the Kenya Country Assistance Strategy (CAS, 1998) and WBI's Client Recording System (CRS) data. Annex 1 presents the data-collection instruments.
KENYAN PARTICIPANT SAMPLE
2.3 The participant sampling procedure comprised identifying from WBI's Client Recording System (CRS) all FY02 and FY03 learning activities that included participants from Kenya. This procedure yielded a list of 93 activities with 727 Kenyan participants.2 After eliminating 35 percent of the participants for whom no contact information (i.e., work phone, fax, email address, or work address) was available, we obtained a sampling frame of 433 participants who had attended 63 activities. We drew a 33 percent random sample from this sampling frame for collecting survey and focus group data. Annex 2 presents the list of activities included in the sample.
2.4 The sampling procedure highlighted the disturbing fact that contact information was missing for a sizable portion of Kenyan participants, thereby excluding the possibilities for follow-up for further WBI activities or for evaluation.
Participant Sampling Results
2.5 The final participant sample comprised 144 Kenyan nationals who had participated in 47 WBI learning activities during FY02 and FY03. The sample represented 20 percent of the total Kenyan participant population and 50 percent of the activities.

Time elapsed between activity implementation and data collection ranged from 10 to 30 months. Contact information was incorrect or old for 39 (27 percent) of the original sample of 144 participants. We used a replacement sample list to supplement the original sample, drawn from the same activities and programs, where possible. A total of 133 completed participant questionnaires were received, for a response rate of approximately 92 percent.
2.7 Sixty-four percent of the survey respondents are male and 36 percent are female. Approximately 32 percent worked in government at various levels (see Figure 1). The participants were composed of nearly equal proportions of junior/entry-, mid-, and senior/top-level staff (see Figure 2).

7  3. RELEVANCE OF WBI LEARNING ACTIVITIES
3.1 We assessed the relevance of WBI's FY02-03 activities to Kenya in two ways. First, the analysis focused on the participants' assessments of activity relevance, and second, we determined the alignment of the activities FY02-FY04 activities to the 1998 Country Assistance Strategy (CAS). This exercise was conducted to obtain a baseline for future reference, as WBI reorients its programs in the priority countries, including Kenya.
PARTICIPANTS' ASSESSMENTSOF ACTIVITY RELEVANCE
3.2 The participants provided their assessments of the learning activities' relevance to Kenya's development needs, to their own work, and to the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and the Bank's corporate priorities. These results are discussed below.
Activity Relevance to Kenya's Needs and to Participants' Work
3.3 Overall, twenty six percent of Kenyans indicated that the activity they attended had been designed for participants from their country. If we consider activity-level data, only 9 of the 38 activities with respondent data, or 24 percent, were considered to be designed specifically for the participants from Kenya.5
3.4 However, the participants provided moderately high ratings on activity relevance, with mean ratings of 5.8 on relevance to Kenya's specific needs and 5.1 on relevance to the participants' own work (on a scale of 1 to 7, with 1 denoting "not relevant at all" and 7 denoting "extremely relevant").
3.5 Sixty nine percent of Kenyan participants' perceived the activity they attended to be highly relevant to Kenya's specific needs. Only 1 percent perceived the topics covered by WBI learning activities to be not relevant at all. In contrast, participants' assessments of the relevance of the activity to their work was considerably lower; only 44 percent considered the activity to be highly relevant, and 5 percent considered it to be not relevant to the work they do.
3.6 This feedback indicates that while the activities targeted the general issues of concern to Kenya, a sizable proportion of the participants did not take away from them specific knowledge or skills they could apply to their jobs (more on this issue in Chapter 4).
Activity Relevance to MDGs
3.7 A vast majority of the participants, 85 percent, reported that the activity they attended was related to eradication of extreme poverty. A significant proportion of the

RELEVANCEOF ACTIVITIES TO CAS
3.11 We assessed the alignment of WBI's in-country and out-of-country activities for participants from Kenya with the 1998 CAS recommendations. The steps to deriving the alignment index included: (1) reviewing and summarizing the CAS recommendations by WBI thematic programs7; (2) listing all WBI activities (FY02-FY04) by thematic programs; and (3) calculating percent alignment by dividing the total number of thematic programs with both CAS recommendations and WBI activities by the total number of programs with WBI activities (with or without CAS recommendations). The same set of steps was followed for assessing alignment with lending operations.
3.12 The alignment index for WBI activities with CAS recommendations is 56 percent, and for lending projects it is 79 percent. There was clear non-alignment in seven programs that were delivered without a specific CAS recommendation. It should be noted, however, that the Bank program changed substantially between 1998 and 2002, due to the changes in political circumstances8, and therefore the activities in reality may have been more aligned with the Bank's approach.
3.13 Going forward, FY05 and beyond, the CAS-WBI alignment index should improve with the new CAS (May 19, 2004) as the Kenya WBI program of activities is decided in consultation with the country team on the basis of the new CAS. Annex 3 provides more details on alignment.
BANKSTAFF ASSESSMENTOF ACTIVITY RELEVANCE AND USEFULNESS
3.14 Kenya is host to two WBI Capacity Enhancement initiatives9, one on investment climate and the other on implementing the Rapid Results approach to help the Government of Kenya finalize and implement its economic recovery strategy.
3.15 Interview data reveal that the two initiatives and the country-focused approach have fostered productive relations between WBI and the Kenya country team. WBI is represented on the CAS team, and WBI thematic program staff in Education and Public Sector are working closely with the country sector staff. A key member of the country team reported that WBI activities are better aligned with the country strategy and more relevant to Kenya's needs than they were prior to FY04.
3.16 Bank staff also reported that WBI still has "...a somewhat supply driven approach and tends to come with its menu rather than developing its interventions based on the

11  4. EFFECTIVENESS AND IMPACT OF WBI LEARNING ACTIVITIES
4.1 We asked the participants to rate the effectiveness and impact of the learning activities they attended through several questions. This chapter presents the participants' responses as well as some multivariate analyses regarding the determinants of effectiveness and impact.
EFFECTIVENESSOF WBI LEARNING ACTIVITIES
4.2 The evaluation measured six aspects of effectiveness anticipated for the WBI learning activities:
· Raising participants' awareness/understanding of development issues important to their country,
· Providing participants with knowledge/skills,
· Helping participants understand their role in their country's development,
· Helping participants develop strategies/approaches to address the needs of their organization,
· Helping participants develop strategies/approaches to address the needs of their country, and
· Helping participants develop contacts and partnerships and build coalitions (Network).
Participant Ratings of Activity Effectiveness
4.3 Participants provided an overall average rating of 5.51, indicating that the activities were considered to be slightly above moderately effective. The average was computed over the six dimensions of effectiveness measured on a seven-point scale10, from 1 denoting "not at all effective" to 7 indicating "extremely effective."
4.4 Results disaggregated by the six dimensions of effectiveness reveal that a slim majority considered the activity to be highly effective (see Figure 5). Activities were most effective in helping participants understand their role in development but relatively less effective in helping participants network. Activity effectiveness was also on the lower end with respect to helping participants address the needs of their organization.

4.5 The findings underscore the need for clearly articulating the goals of WBI activities. If the primary goal is for advocacy and to raise participants' awareness, the activities were largely successful. However, if the goals were to assist with networking or implementing organizational change strategies, the activities cannot be considered to be as successful.
Determinants of Effectiveness
4.6 On the basis of previous research11 and the assumptions underlying WBI's country-focused direction, we hypothesized that a number of activity-related variables would be positively related to participants' ratings of effectiveness12. We modeled an Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) regression as follows:
Effectiveness = 0 + 1 (Activity Features) + 2 (Participant Characteristics) +
4.7 The activity features investigated include development of action-plans13 during activity implementation, activity duration, and mode of instruction (including face-to- face, distance learning, web-based learning, and other), and percent Kenyan participants attending the activity. The key participant characteristics included participants' proficiency in the technical terminology of the learning activity, sex, and type of position as controls (see Table 4). 18  5. WBI'S SUSTAINED PRESENCE AND COMPARATIVE ADVANTAGE
5.1 The evaluation assessed the degree to which WBI activities have a sustained presence in Kenya, thereby facilitating the development of in-country capacity on an on- going basis. We also addressed the issue of whether WBI has a comparative advantage in Kenya to undertake this complex task.
WBI'S SUSTAINED PRESENCE
5.2 We used two indicators of sustained presence: (a) whether or not contact information or newsletters were provided to facilitate on-going networking and therefore exchange of information and ideas among the participants; and (b) whether follow-up to the learning activity was implemented. The FY00-01 Impact Study identified these measures of post-activity support to be key factors for use of knowledge and skills gained in the learning activity and, ultimately, impact.
5.3 On the positive side, 68 percent of the participants reported receiving contact information for fellow participants. Among these, a majority, 60 percent, used the contact information to organize discussions and 14 percent used the information to organize follow-up activities. However, almost a quarter of the participants, 26 percent, never used the contact information
5.4 On the negative side, nearly 53 percent of the participants reported that there was no follow-up contact by WBI, and only 25 percent of the participants contacted WBI to follow-up on issues regarding or questions about the content of the learning activity.
5.5 Participants' focus group and interview feedback indicated that WBI activities did not encourage ownership and institutionalization of the learning process in Kenya, even through participants found the activities to be useful and informative. Despite (or perhaps because of) the wide variety of learning activities and various modes of delivery offered by WBI, the consensus among participants (and many Bank staff) is that the learning process is supply-driven, and, therefore did not encourage Kenya to either use the learning for substantial sectoral/institutional change or to take the learning process forward (see Box 1).
Box 1. Focus Group Analysis by SBO-Research
Past learning activities experienced considerable shortcomings as a result of inadequate follow up. It is difficult to ascertain WBI's objectives and commitment if it simply pumps resources into training manpower and does not have follow up. Participants' observations were as follows: · "There should be a system for continuity, follow up, and feedback." · "That was the introduction course. When are we doing the real thing? The next stage should run to completion." · "The World Bank should franchise some institutions locally to conduct the learning activities on a continuous basis ­ have a resource person to be able to train others."
19  5.6 Recommendations from both the participant focus group and Bank staff interviews underscored two major points: (a) the need to base future WBI programs on better needs assessment and (b) to make the program more demand driven.
WBI'S COMPARATIVE ADVANTAGE
5.7 We assessed WBI's comparative advantage in Kenya by asking participants to compare the quality of the WBI activity they attended to that of the activities/services provided by other institutions.
5.8 WBI appears not to have much competition from other institutions in the programmatic areas that were active in Kenya during FY02-03. Only 22 percent of the respondents were aware of similar activities being provided by other organizations. Of these 22 percent, 25 percent identified competition from non-WBI sources in Environment, followed by Attacking Poverty (17 percent) and Private Sector Development program (18 percent). Good Governance, a program that offered numerous activities in Kenya faced negligible competition from non-WBI sources (only 3 participants were aware of non-WBI activities in this field).
5.9 Participants noted that the activities provided by other institutions were on average less effective than the WBI learning activity they attended. The average rating comparing WBI activities to non-WBI activities was 5.3 on a scale of 1 to 7, with 1 indicating that the WBI activity was much less useful, 4 denoting that both were about the same, and 7 denoting that the WBI activity was much more useful.
5.10 Focus group participants' remarks highlight the value they ascribe to WBI programs:
· "The alternatives of such learning activities are less value for money compared to the WBI activities."
· "The willingness to pay is there, but the ability to pay is lacking...I tried to get in touch with WBI to find out where I could get support to do the course, but I never heard from them again."
5.11 Although WBI appears to have a comparative advantage in the programmatic activities it offers to Kenyan participants, there has been much less effort in ensuring that the initial investments made through the activities pay off on a longer term basis through the provision of on-going support and follow up.
20  6. CONCLUSIONS AND RECOMMENDATIONS
6.1 This chapter summarizes the main findings and conclusions and offers three key recommendations.
FINDINGS AND CONCLUSIONS
The Client Recording System needs substantial improvement.
6.2 The Client Recording System data is missing contact information on a substantial proportion, 35 percent, of Kenyan participants, thereby excluding the possibility for follow-up for further learning activities or for evaluation.
The pattern of participant ratings suggests that activities did not adequately target the institutional dimensions of capacity building.
6.3 A large majority, sixty nine percent of Kenyan participants' perceived the activity they attended to be highly relevant to Kenya's specific needs, but only 44 percent considered the activity to be highly relevant to their work. This finding underscores the need to provide demand-driven activities to ensure that they are more pertinent and useful for Kenyan participants' work.
6.4 The alignment of WBI activities The alignment of WBI's FY02 and FY03 activities to the 1998 CAS recommendations was 56 percent, indicating, that a substantial proportion of WBI programs delivered were unrelated to the country strategy articulated in the CAS. It should be noted, however, that the Bank program changed substantially between 1998 and 2002, due to the changes in political circumstances, and therefore the activities may have been more aligned with the Bank's approach. The WBI-CAS alignment index should improve with the implementation of WBI's country-focused approach and the development of the new 2004 CAS.
6.5 The participants' ratings reveal that WBI activities were moderately effective, but their impact was less significant. Only 45 to 27 percent of the participants reported high use, and 11 to 24 percent made little to no use, of knowledge and skills in specific domains relevant to their work. The fact that 17 to 24 percent of the participants did not use the knowledge and skills they gained for work practices, country development, and influencing legislation suggests that the activity they attended did not lend itself to use for direct institutional/country development purposes.
6.6 Interviews with Bank staff indicate that activity relevance and use may be enhance through better needs assessment and targeting of participants.
6.7 The use of action plans as a pedagogical tool and activity relevance to Kenya's needs and to participants' work were significant predictors of activity effectiveness.
21  Effectiveness in turn was significantly related to the participants' use of the knowledge and skills they gained in the learning activity.
6.8 Activity relevance to work, effectiveness for addressing organizational needs and use for influencing legislation were on the lower end of participant ratings.
· Although WBI's comparative advantage is clear, WBI activities did not have a sustained presence in Kenya, also contributing to less than optimal impact.
6.9 Fewer than 25 percent of the participants were aware of activities similar to WBI's being offered by other organizations. On average, participants rated WBI activities to be more useful than those provided by other organizations.
6.10 Sixty eight percent of the participants reported receiving contact information for fellow participants, but nearly 53 percent of the participants reported that there was no follow-up contact by WBI. Focus group participants indicated that WBI activity participants see follow up as key to activity success.
RECOMMENDATIONS
6.11 WBI's demand-driven, country-focused direction in support of CAS should improve the overall relevance, effectiveness, and impact of WBI activities FY04 and beyond. Nonetheless, key activity design features, implementation, and targeting will need attention, if sustained institutional impact is the goal of WBI presence in Kenya. Some recommendations follow.
§ Design activities that include follow-up and on-going contact with participants. Activities of this nature will require a careful targeting of participants for institutional impact.
§ Include action plans as part of activity implementation to help participants apply what they learn to their jobs.
§ Improve CRS participant information. Demand for activities with more WBI follow-up and on-going contact should create an incentive for WBI task managers to gather and report accurate participant contact information.

doc.repnme: The impact of WBI activities FY02-03 on participants from Kenya : A baseline assessment
doc.abstracts: The primary goal of the World Bank Institute (WBI) is to provide knowledge services to build institutional capacity in client countries. In FY03, WBI launched a new approach to providing services that are country-focused, multi-year programs linked to Bank country assistance strategies and the client's own poverty reduction goals. WBI in coordination with Regional Vice Presidencies identified a group of 30 countries in which to concentrate this new approach initially, starting in FY04. In support of the country-focused approach, WBI's Evaluation Group (IEG) concurrently initiated a series of evaluations to establish country-specific results to serve as baselines in the priority countries. This report focuses on WBI activities implemented in Kenya in FY02 and FY03. The evaluation addresses the following three main questions. What is the relevance of WBI learning activities to Kenya and Kenyan participants? What are the effectiveness and impact of WBI learning activities? Do WBI activities have a sustained presence and comparative advantage in Kenya?
